articles.title: About PMR Data Consulting
articles.description: Who we are and what we do
articles.contents:
Peter Rabinovitch
is the founder of PMR Data Consulting. He has extensive real world data
science experience with some of the largest technology companies in the
world, as well as the theoretical knowledge afforded by a PhD in
Probability and Statistics. He has co-led Data For Good
Ottawa, a group of volunteer data
scientists who apply their expertise to solve the problems of local
charities. He shares his expertise with MBA students at the University
of Ottawa, meetup groups, and colleagues.


Our approach to data science (click the triangles to see details):

All real-world data sets contain anomalies
It is the job of the data scientist to ensure that anomalies are caught,
mitigated, and most importantly, that their impact is understood by
stakeholders before business decisions are made.
Anomalies may be data entry errors, coding errors, or some facet of your business that you do not yet understand.
The important question is “what do the anomalies mean to your business’s bottom line?”

Using just one number to describe any real-world scenario is
misleading
Your business is too complex to be captured by just one metric. You also
need to know a likely range for the metric (eg. a confidence interval),
and how this metric interacts with other metrics.

Data insights must speak the language of your business, or their value
may be lost
If these insights aren’t expressed in terms that resonate with business objectives and decision making processes, their potential to drive meaningful action and create value may be diminished.
Guided by these principles, PMR Data Consulting specializes in
helping businesses, large and small, extract the most important insights from their data.

articles.title: Understand Your Donor Base
articles.description: Analyzing the size of a donor base over time
articles.contents:
In this project, the organization was concerned about their shrinking donations.
Initial analysis suggested that although the donations per donor were steady, that perhaps the donor base was shrinking.
Further analysis looked at the size of the pool of donors, and grouped them into categories of ‘new’ and ‘lapsed’.
A plot of the cumulative number of each group confirms the suspicion.



In the early 2000’s, there were many more new donors than lapsed donors. But as we progress we find that there are fewer new donors and more lapsed donors each year. In 2015 there were more lapsed donors than new donors for the first time.
Although the details of this plot depend on how ‘new donor’ and ‘lapsed donor’ are defined, changing these definitions somewhat has little effect on the conclusion: the donor pool is shrinking.
This finding allowed the organization to focus its efforts in three areas:
acquiring more new donors,
recapturing lapsed donors,
preventing donors from lapsing
We can also perform customer lifetime value (CLV) analyses that can help you assess the value of each customer to your business over the long term.

articles.title: Understand the Quality of Your Data
articles.description: Is my data good enough for my purposes?
articles.contents:
Before starting on any statistical analysis, it is important to know the quality of the data upon which the analysis will be based. We can perform a data quality assessment that provides overall assessments and recommendations for improving data quality.
Data quality is a continuum. The quality of a data set must be assessed with respect to its intended use, and the potential impact of any results derived from the data.

In the example above, we plot daily unit sales figures. Attempts to predict sales based on this data may prove difficult if the anomalies in the data are not addressed.

articles.title: Understand the Business Forecasts
articles.contents:
Forecasts of sales, costs, and cash flow are essential tools for your business planning.
Forecasts should always include an indication of the uncertainty in the predictions (shown in green below) so that you can plan for each likely outcome. Think of forecasts as possible futures, from which you can assess different business outcomes and make decisions based on their likelihoods.

Forecasts can be done for your business to understand demand, costs, or any other metrics.
We can also perform impact analyses that help determine the effect of an intervention on any metric, for example the impact of an advertising campaign on your sales.

articles.title: Understand the Demand for Your Products
articles.description: Impactful insights hidden in demand data
articles.contents:
This project, for the Ottawa Food Bank, had the goal of understanding demand for different types of food in the different Ottawa wards, over time.
We built a custom app to aid with this task. One of the most interesting insights found was that the Ottawa Food Bank was providing diapers for one-fifth of the two month old babies in the Rideau Vanier ward. This statement could then be used in showing donors the huge impact they were having in the community.

Similar analyses can be done for any business to understand demand for its products.
